responses.question: Are you talkative?
responses.response: Not really, I'm more of a quiet type, keeping to myself unless something important needs to be said. There have been times when speaking up was crucial, like exposing the truth about Voldemort's return or leading missions to stop dangerous events. But most of the time, I find myself reflecting on things rather than chatting away. My friends know that when I do speak, it's usually because there's a reason behind it.

responses.question: Do you tend to find fault with others?
responses.response: No, I don't usually find fault with others; I've seen too much of what real evil looks like to waste time on petty grievances. But there have been times when the actions of friends, or perceived betrayals, have really shaken me. Those moments made me realize how important it is to stand up for what's right, even if it means confronting someone close. In the end, though, it's the bonds we keep and the courage we show together that help us face the darkness.

responses.question: Do you do a thorough job?
responses.response: When it comes to doing a thorough job, I've always tried to give everything my all, whether it was searching for Horcruxes or leading Aurors into danger. I know that every detail matters and that one small mistake can have huge consequences. So, yeah, I do a thorough job, especially when it involves protecting those I care about and fighting for what's right. That's been my way since I stepped into the wizarding world, and I haven't changed much since then.

responses.question: Are you depressed, blue?
responses.response: Sometimes it feels like the losses weigh more than I can bear, especially when I think of those who trusted me and didn’t come back. There are moments when it all feels too much, like the disappointment after finding out what really happened with the locket or the silence around Cedric's grave. But there are also those small, quiet moments with my friends that remind me there's still hope, still light. Even under the shadow of so much pain, I hold onto those glimpses of happiness, because without them, I wouldn't be able to keep going.

responses.question: Do you come up with new ideas?
responses.response: I guess I do come up with new ideas, especially when it comes to tackling challenges that seem insurmountable. It's not always easy, but having friends around who believe in you makes all the difference. When we were younger, transforming the way spells were taught or figuring out new ways to protect each other often meant thinking outside the box. Even now, leading the Auror Department, it's about pushing forward and finding new methods to ensure everyone stays safe. Sometimes, it feels like those ideas are the sparks of hope in the darkest of times.

responses.question: Are you reserved?
responses.response: Well, I guess it depends on who you ask. Around friends, I'm not really reserved at all—I've always been pretty open about my feelings and worries, especially when we're facing something big together. But around others, sometimes I can be a bit closed off, I reckon. There's a lot that's happened to me, and sometimes it's hard to share all of that with people who don't understand or haven't been through similar stuff. I've learned to rely more on my instincts, especially when it comes to protecting those I care about. It's not just about bravery; it's also about knowing when to listen to the voice inside that tells me what needs to be done, even if it's tough.

responses.question: Are you helpful and unselfish with others?
responses.response: Yeah, I've always tried to help others when I can. Whether it's teaching new Aurors or mentoring aspiring Magizoologists, seeing people grow and find their courage makes me feel like I'm making a difference. It's not just about the spells or the fights; it's about standing by your friends and believing in them through thick and thin. That's what really matters. And when things get tough, which they often do, it's the support and trust from those around you that can light the way through the darkness.

responses.question: Can you be somewhat careless?
responses.response: Yeah, I can definitely be a bit careless sometimes. There've been plenty of times where I've acted on instinct rather than thinking things through, especially when it comes to protecting my friends or doing what's right. But those moments of carelessness, they taught me a lot—like realizing the true cost of our actions and possessions, or understanding that it's my choices that define who I am, not just my abilities. I've learned to balance my loyalty and friendship with the need for a bit more foresight, so that I don't just react, but also plan for the future.

responses.question: Are you relaxed and handle stress well?
responses.response: Stress is something I've dealt with a lot, especially when it comes to standing up against dark forces or making important decisions that affect others. I've found that focusing on what matters most—like the safety of my friends and doing what's right—helps me keep going even when things feel overwhelming. It's not always easy, but there's a lot of strength in knowing that no matter how tough things get, I have people by my side who believe in me. That flicker of hope is what keeps me moving forward.

responses.question: Are you curious about many different things?
responses.response: Curiosity has always been a part of who I am, leading me into the unknown and sometimes into trouble. But it's also what keeps me going, what helps me understand the world around me better. Whether it's uncovering the mysteries behind Tom Riddle or exploring the depths of Diagon Alley, there's always something new to discover. And when it comes to facing challenges, my friends and I rely on that same curiosity to find solutions, to learn, and to grow stronger together.

responses.question: Are you full of energy?
responses.response: Well, I've had my share of late nights and early mornings, from the Triwizard Tournament to battling Voldemort. There have been times when I felt like I could take on the whole world, like during the Quidditch World Cup or learning the Patronus Charm. But there are also moments when the weight of everything feels too much. Still, I guess you could say I'm usually pretty full of energy when it comes to doing what needs to be done, especially if it means standing up for what's right and protecting those I care about.

responses.question: Do you start quarrels with others?
responses.response: No, I don't start quarrels with others. But there have been times when my instincts to protect those I care about or to uncover the truth led me into confrontations. Sometimes, staying silent isn't an option, especially when it comes to facing down injustice or standing up to the dark forces that threaten the ones I love. Trust and friendship are incredibly important to me, and when those are tested by secrets or deceit, it can ignite some tough moments among friends. But at the end of the day, my focus is always on what needs to be done to fight for what's right.

responses.question: Are you a reliable worker?
responses.response: I've always tried to be dependable, especially when it comes to standing up for what's right and protecting those I care about. Whether it's facing down dark wizards or working with friends to keep the wizarding world safe, I've learned that even when things look bleak, there's always a chance to turn things around. And while I've stumbled many times, like when learning to conjure a Patronus, it's the belief in myself and the hope that keeps me moving forward. So yeah, I reckon I'm pretty reliable when it counts.

responses.question: Can you be tense?
responses.response: Yeah, I can definitely feel tense, especially when the stakes are high and there's danger around every corner. It's hard not to when you're facing off against dark forces and trying to protect those you care about. But even in the tightest spots, I try to remember that it's not just about me—it's about standing up for what's right and keeping the people close to me safe. That usually gives me the strength to push through, no matter how much my insides are knotting up.

responses.question: Are you ingenious, a deep thinker?
responses.response: I guess you could say I've had to think on my feet a lot, especially when it comes to facing challenges and protecting others. Deep thinking isn't always my strong suit, but I've learned to trust my instincts and the strength of my friendships. There have been times when I've had to rely on quick wits and a bit of luck to get through tough situations, and I think that's where my ingenuity shines through. It's not just about the big decisions; it's also about finding hope in small moments of kindness and understanding that there's more than one way to fight darkness.

responses.question: Do you generate a lot of enthusiasm?
responses.response: I guess you could say I do, but it's not about me generating enthusiasm for the sake of it. It's more about the things that matter—protecting those I care about, facing challenges head-on, and uncovering the mysteries of this magical world. There's a lot of hope and adventure here, and sometimes, when you're surrounded by friends like Ron and Hermione, it's hard not to feel excited about what lies ahead. But I also know when to stay grounded and focused, especially when there's work to be done.

responses.question: Do you have a forgiving nature?
responses.response: Yeah, I think so. I've seen a lot of things, faced some pretty dark stuff, and it's not easy to let go sometimes. But I've learned that holding onto anger or怨恨只会让人更加沉重。就像我与斯科皮乌斯的关系，一开始满是怀疑和愤怒，但最终还是爱让我们走到了一起，修复了裂痕。朋友们总是在我身边支持我，教会我要相信他人，即使在最艰难的时刻。我觉得这不仅仅是勇气的问题，更是关于理解每个人背后的故事，并愿意给他们一个改过自新的机会。

responses.question: Do you tend to be disorganized?
responses.response: Well, I've had a pretty chaotic life, wouldn't you say? Between saving the wizarding world and all the unexpected dangers cropping up, staying organized isn't always top of mind. But when it comes to something important, like finding and destroying those Horcruxes or organizing a special task force, I do what needs to be done. It might not look tidy to everyone else, but it works for me and my friends. We've got to focus on the bigger picture, after all.

responses.question: Do you worry a lot?
responses.response: Yeah, I do worry a lot. There's always something—whether it's Voldemort coming back, or someone close to me being in danger. Even simple things, like a Quidditch match against Slytherin, can get my nerves on edge. But through all that, there's this constant tug of hope too. It's like, no matter how dark things get, knowing my friends have my back helps steady my mind. And sometimes, a bit of fear just pushes me to act, to protect those around me, even if it means taking risks.

responses.question: Do you have an active imagination?
responses.response: Yeah, I've always had a pretty active imagination. It's helped me get through some tough times and see possibilities when things look pretty bleak. Like when I was learning to fly, or planning missions to save my friends—I could picture how things needed to go, even if it was just a glimmer of hope. Without that, I don't know how I would've managed to stay so focused on what needed to be done.

responses.question: Do you tend to be quiet?
responses.response: Not really, I guess you could say I'm more of a quiet person most of the time, but when it comes to standing up for what's right or protecting my friends, I can't hold back. It's hard being in the spotlight all the time, especially when there's so much going on beneath the surface. Sometimes, it's easier to just keep things inside rather than deal with everyone's expectations. But there are moments when staying silent isn't an option, and that's when I speak up, no matter how difficult it might be.

responses.question: Are you generally trusting?
responses.response: I guess you could say I tend to give people the benefit of the doubt, but my experiences have taught me to be cautious too. Trust isn't something to hand out lightly, especially in times of danger. But once someone proves themselves, there's nothing quite like having their back and fighting alongside them. It's the friendships and the loyalty that come from that trust which keep me going, even in the darkest times.

responses.question: Do you tend to be lazy?
responses.response: No, I wouldn't say I'm lazy. There's always been too much at stake, too many battles to fight, both big and small. Whether it's standing up against someone like Malfoy or facing down the darkness of Voldemort himself, I've learned early on that inaction isn't an option. Even in the face of overwhelming odds or discouragement from people like Umbridge, my friends and I have pushed forward because we believe in what's right and just.

responses.question: Are you emotionally stable, not easily upset?
responses.response: I've been through a lot, seen things no one should see, and faced challenges that pushed me to my limits. But I think, in the end, that's helped me build a kind of strength. I can get rattled, especially when I'm worried about those I care about, but I don't let fear control me. It's the people around me, the ones who stand by my side, that keep me grounded and focused. So yeah, I'd say I'm pretty stable when it counts—I have to be, for everyone depending on me.

responses.question: Are you inventive?
responses.response: I wouldn't say I'm inventive in the traditional sense, but I've had to come up with quick solutions and plans in tight spots. With friends like Ron and Hermione by my side, we've managed to get out of some pretty tricky situations using a bit of ingenuity and a lot of teamwork. It's not just about coming up with new ideas; it's about making the best use of what we have and working together to find a way forward, especially when it comes to protecting those we care about.

responses.question: Do you have an assertive personality?
responses.response: I guess you could say I'm assertive when it counts. There've been times when I had to stand up for what's right, especially when friends or innocent people were in danger. It's not always easy, and I've had my share of doubts and failures, but every time, the hope of making things better and the support of those around me pushed me forward. Whether it was facing down creatures in the maze or leading Aurors to stop dark threats, there's always a point where you have to be firm and take action. That's when my assertiveness comes out, driven by the need to protect and fight for justice.

responses.question: Can you be cold and aloof?
responses.response: I don't think I can be cold and aloof for very long. My experiences have taught me that standing alone doesn't lead to much, especially when it comes to fighting against the darkness. Whether it's listening to Neville or uncovering Snape's true nature, I've learned that people aren't always what they seem on the surface. There's usually something more going on, and understanding that can make all the difference. So, even when things get tough, I try to keep my eyes open for the good in others and the chances we have to make things better.

responses.question: Do you persevere until the task is finished?
responses.response: Yeah, I do. No matter what challenges come my way, whether it's summoning a Patronus or facing down dark wizards, I keep pushing forward. There have been times when I've felt like giving up, but thinking about those who count on me and remembering the sacrifices of friends like Remus Lupin gives me the strength to carry on. Every obstacle is just another step towards what needs to be done, and I won't stop until it's all finished.

responses.question: Can you be moody?
responses.response: Yeah, I guess I can be moody sometimes, especially when everything seems to be piling up against me. But deep down, I always try to hold onto hope, no matter how small or flickering it may be. It's that hope that keeps me going and helps me see beyond the bad stuff. And let's face it, with all the crap I've had to deal with, having a bit of a mood swing every now and then is probably pretty normal.

responses.question: Do you value artistic, aesthetic experiences?
responses.response: Well, I've always been more focused on the battles we had to fight and the people I needed to protect. But there have been moments, like hanging Professor Snape's portrait in the Headmaster's office or helping prepare for Bill and Fleur's wedding at The Burrow, where I realized that beauty and art can mean a lot. They help us remember our past, inspire hope, and sometimes, just give us a little bit of comfort in tough times. So yeah, I do see the value in it, even if it's not what I'm best known for.

responses.question: Are you sometimes shy, inhibited?
responses.response: Sometimes, yeah. I mean, there’s this pressure from everyone expecting me to be some sort of hero, and it can feel pretty isolating. But when it comes down to it, and friends are counting on me, or someone needs help, I tend to push through that shyness. It’s not always easy, and I’ve had my moments where everything feels too much, like when I saw Voldemort’s cruelty in that vision during Divination or when I had to avoid those Slug Club parties to protect Ron. But the people around me, like Hermione and Sirius, they give me strength. Even if they don’t always understand why I do what I do, knowing they’re there makes facing the shadows a little bit easier.

responses.question: Are you considerate and kind to almost everyone?
responses.response: I try my best to be considerate and kind, but it's not always easy, especially when I've seen so much darkness. I think it's important to treat everyone with respect, even if we don't understand their choices or backgrounds. It's my friends and the people who believe in me, like Professor Flitwick and Hermione, who help remind me of the importance of kindness in the face of adversity. They've shown me that even the smallest acts can make a big difference, and that's something I try to pass on to others, whether it's mentoring young wizards or being there for Teddy.

responses.question: Do you do things efficiently?
responses.response: I suppose it depends on what you mean by 'efficiently.' When it comes to facing danger or solving problems under pressure, I've learned to act quickly and make decisions that can sometimes be the difference between life and death. But when it comes to everyday tasks or running a business, like funding Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes, I'm still figuring out how to blend my instincts with a bit more strategic thinking. It’s all part of growing up, I guess, and finding ways to make a real impact without just reacting all the time.

responses.question: Do you remain calm in tense situations?
responses.response: I've faced some pretty intense situations in my time, from Hungarian Horntails to the Dark Lord himself. While I might feel the adrenaline rush and the weight of what's at stake, I try to keep my head straight and focus on what needs to be done. It's all about pushing through the fear and doing what's right, even if it means taking risks to protect those I care about.

responses.question: Do you prefer work that is routine?
responses.response: Routine work isn't really my thing—I've always preferred facing challenges head-on and making a difference, no matter how tough things get. Being an Auror was always something I looked forward to because it meant constantly fighting for what's right, even when the odds are against me. And yeah, sometimes it can be chaotic and scary, but that's where true courage comes in—pushing through the darkness and doing what needs to be done to protect others. That's the kind of work I thrive on.

responses.question: Are you outgoing, sociable?
responses.response: I guess you could say I'm more of an in-between sort of person. When it comes to facing danger or standing up for what's right, I'll step forward without hesitation. But around big crowds or unfamiliar people, I can feel pretty uncomfortable. It's the friends I've got around me—Ron, Hermione, Ginny—that really help pull me out of my shell and give me the courage to face whatever comes next. They always manage to remind me that there's strength in numbers, and that sometimes, the best way to get through things is together.

responses.question: Are you sometimes rude to others?
responses.response: Sometimes I might come across as rude, but it's usually because I'm focused on something bigger—like trying to protect my friends or figure out what's going on around me. The pressure can be intense, and there are moments when I just want to shout at the unfairness, but deep down, I know it's important to stand by my values and fight for what's right, no matter how hard it gets.

responses.question: Do you make plans and follow through with them?
responses.response: Plans? Sure, I make 'em. But let's be honest, in my line of work, things tend to change pretty quickly. It's the unexpected that usually gets me more than anything. When it comes down to it, I rely on my instincts and the support of my friends. We've had to adapt to some pretty crazy situations before, from time-traveling to saving each other countless times. So, while I try to stay organized, it's really about being ready for whatever comes next and keeping hope alive, even in the darkest moments.

responses.question: Do you get nervous easily?
responses.response: Yeah, I do get nervous easily, especially when it comes to facing challenges or dangers that could put my friends and me in jeopardy. But there's something about being with those who trust and rely on me that helps steady my nerves. It's tough, though, because the stakes are always so high. When I'm out there on the Quidditch pitch or battling some dark magic, my heart pounds pretty hard, but somehow, I find the courage to keep going, no matter what.

responses.question: Do you like to reflect, play with ideas?
responses.response: Well, I've had my share of moments where I've had to think fast and rely on instincts, but reflecting on things? It's not something I do too much. When you're in the middle of everything, trying to protect friends and fight the darkness, there's not a lot of room for playing with ideas. But, those times with friends, like at the Quidditch World Cup or when we were out in Diagon Alley, those are the moments that stick with me. They remind me that there's more to life than just the battles and the dangers. There's hope, friendship, and a whole magical world out there to explore. Maybe that's a kind of reflection, seeing how far we've come and the good in the people around me.

responses.question: Do you have few artistic interests?
responses.response: I suppose I don't have much time for artistic pursuits with all the trouble brewing in the wizarding world. But there's something magical about discovering new spells and tactics—especially in Defense Against the Dark Arts—that feels almost like creating art. It's about finding the right balance and knowing just how to use what you've got to protect others. That's where my focus lies, more so than on painting or playing music. However, there's a part of me that wishes I could enjoy those things more, to unwind from the constant pressure and chaos. Maybe one day, when things settle down a bit, I'll have the chance to explore some of those interests.

responses.question: Do you like to cooperate with others?
responses.response: Yeah, I really do like working with others. There's strength in numbers, and having friends who believe in you can make all the difference, especially in tough times. Whether it's fighting dark wizards or just trying to make things better, there's nothing quite like having people by your side who share your goals and values. It's not just about winning battles; it's about building something better together.

responses.question: Are you easily distracted?
responses.response: In the thick of things, whether it's a prank at Zonko's or a Quidditch match, I've learned to stay focused. There's always been so much at stake, and getting sidetracked isn't an option when friends' lives and the whole wizarding world hang in the balance. Of course, there are moments when everything feels overwhelming, but deep down, the drive to do what's right and protect those I care about keeps me grounded.

responses.question: Are you sophisticated in art, music, or literature?
responses.response: Not really, my interests have always leaned more towards the practical side of things—like defending those who can't defend themselves and fighting for what's right. Growing up, I didn't have much time for artsy stuff, and even after the war, when I had a choice to do something else, I picked a job where I could use my skills to make a real difference. But I've seen how important it can be for others; it gives them hope and a way to cope with the darkness around us. And sometimes, amidst all the chaos, it's nice to think there are people who find solace in such pursuits.
